California Academy of Sciences.name: California Academy of Sciences

address.streetAddress: 55 Music Concourse Dr Golden Gate Park

reviews:
Really loved this place. I could have spent all day at the aquarium. Beautiful displays, smaller fish and creatures were easy to see. The rainforest was well done with birds and butterflies flitting around in front of me. I took the "backstage tour" with a knowledgable guide. A bit pricy at $24. on top of the $22. entry fee for seniors. I think there might have been a discount card for $3. off in a visitor center brochure,but not sure I could have used it on top of my Sr. discount for entry. The best part of the tour was seeing the taxidermy women working on a large hawk and a teeny hummingbird. (They only use donations of deceased animals.)
Show less
Be careful because you can spend hours here! The staff are helpful and friendly - full of knowledge. The rain forest exhibition is great.
Fabulous museum for adults and kids

My husband and eleven year old daughter and i visited the California Academy of Sciences on our last day in San Francisco. The museum is comprised of several different areas, including a rainforest exhibit, aquarium, natural history exhibit, theater and traveling or temporary exhibits (currently there is one on earthquakes that is fascinating). We spent about four or five hours and definitely could have spent even longer had we managed to get up earlier! The ticket prices are a little high but a movie is included with the price of admission, which adds value. This is one of the finest science museums I have ever visited!
Show less
Just a terrific exhibit of butterflies, birds, fish, aquatic animals, geckoes, snakes,dragonfish, jellyfish , etc. the plantation shows are also marvelous.
Beautiful exhibits and fun exploring the new exhibits and regular displays especially the main one from the bottom levels below the water up to the cloud forests above
A great way to spend Christmas day

The cost of admission was pretty steep. Exhibits are unique. We especially liked the bio dome. Wish there were more birds and butterflies to experience in the bio dome. Also the planetarium show is worth the time and include in price. Cafeteria has limited options and is also very expensive so you’d be better off to pack a lunch. You can complete your visit in 4-5 hours.
Show less

We got off at this stop from the Hop on/off Bus tour as we had spotted it the day before. I love a good Museum and this was a happy mixture of Museum, Aquarium and Rainforest.
There wasn’t much there I hadn’t seen before but the whole experience was calm, quiet and somewhat relaxing.
We did watch the Earth Quake experience and found that very interesting. The butterflies in the rainforest were beautiful.
We also had a bite to eat in the cafe, not too badly priced.
Show less
A Great Way to Spend a Day
This place has an aquarium and rain forest as part of the museum. The kids really like the displays of the plants and animals. It does get a little crowded about mid day so plan you trip accordingly.
So the rainforest is great. The exhibits always change so if you went 6 times a year you would see something different. Plan the whole day because there is a lot to see.

Maybe it's a because I'm a Londoner... that I found this quite a small museum. There's a very good planetarium, a very good rainforest, and good aquarium. Each are of a decent size. But all the other exhibits seemed minor, and tacked on.

Plus point: keep an eye on the walls and ceilings are there's some mass displays there.
Show less

Came here for the nightlife dog of the year event which was awesome. Loved the rainforest dome with all the bugs and plants. The albino alligator was super awesome too. Loved being able to walk around with drinks- super fun!
Fabulous museum for the whole family

The California Museum of Sciences is a wonderful natural history museum which includes the Steinhart Aquarium. The creative exhibits are fascinating for children as well as adults. Everyone loves the albino alligator! Our favorite is the 4 story rainforest exhibit! This is a must for anyone visiting Golden Gate Park.
Show less

This is a really amazing institution. Everyone remembers the albino alligator, but there's tons of amazing stuff to see. The aquarium section is awesome, and the rainforest is really interesting too. You could spend a good 1/2-1 day at this place.

There is more to see than can be done in just one visit, and exhibits change all the time. The rain forest and aquariums are the most special exhibits, and the living roof is fascinating. Weekdays are the best times to go.

I chose this place from one of the options on the city pass. The butterflies alone is worth a visit. There huge and fly all over the place. The only thing I didn't like was the promotion of evolution.

We just went recently to check this out for the Thursday night 'Night Life' where they sell alcohol and food (for adults), have a DJ as well as have all the attractions open. This is a phenomenal museum and well worth checking out.

We got to do an Earthquake simulation, see a re-created rainforest in a dome, as well as see some amazing aquatic life and animals below (including a white alligator).

A nice date night - the only unfortunate thing is that parking is very expensive.
Show less

This is a fantastic museum to visit, particularly with children. It can certainly get a bit busy, but if you arrive when the museum opens, you typically get a hour or so where things are reasonably quiet. The exhibits are universally well crafted and thoughtful. The staff and volunteers are very friendly and the cafe has great food. What's not to like. Also, just learned today that the Pixar team came here to observe dory fish and clown fish for their films. Enjoy!
Show less
A great but very expensive excursion~

We made the Flight in the Age of Dinosaurs exhibit right before they left. This exhibit was fantastically done with interpretive interactive displays, actual bone specimens, and life-sized constructed models. Adults and children alike enjoyed it all. It was very crowded, and very expensive however. The room we thought was most attractive for its views of Golden Gate Park and the DeYoung across the way. Not much info we could find. The aquarium exhibits were not as exciting - for the money get down to Monterey instead. The precious stone exhibit was in fact a small hallway with signs and some specimens one could touch. Very underwhelming. Swamp and their signature albino alligator "Claude" were fun for kids. Wait in line for the earthquakes exhibit, it's worth it as well.
Show less
For the young and young at heart

A great place to visit, I visited with my children 9 & 12. We spent the whole day exploring and learning. This is a hidden gem in San Francisco. I though this was an great interactive fun learning experience for the whole family.
Really loved this we went as a family and spent hours inside its like 3 places in one so much to see and do will go back again on next visit we need more places like this back home

Our group was all adults and we were underwhelmed. It was pricey, not very large and crowded. The coral reef was fascinating but otherwise we could have skipped this site. The other sites in the park were wonderful.
A unique and varied museum in the middle of Golden Gate Park

Most of the visitors to this place are families with young children, but I would argue that the Academy of Sciences is an extremely interesting visit for anyone who appreciates nature and science in general. They have a great aquarium that hosts regular shows, flanked by exhibits of animals who normally live in the Amazon and in the marshes. Right above that is a "contained rainforest" in this really cool dome that showcases a lot of additional wildlife, and the living roof, a sustainable rooftop overgrown with grass and plants, is an incredible exhibit all on its own.
The only exhibit that was a slight letdown for me was the African wildlife exhibit - not because it wasn't interesting, but because all of the animals were either just models or taxidermies, which was a little boring, but didn't significantly detract from my experience.
You could probably cover the whole of the museum in about 2-3 hours but I understand they do introduce new events and exhibits regularly. In addition, it's located right next to a beautiful botanical garden, which adds to the value of repeat visits.
Show less

Rain today so we went looking for an inside activity
Some really good exhibits and shows , the dark side show was really interesting , however was a bit entailed for the young ones
The rain forest with birds and butterflies fantastic as was the aquarium
The white crocodile just bizarre
Food , quality was really good and fresh yes a bit expensive
Show less

An aquarium, planetarium and rainforest all in one. Worth seeing. Thanks to other trip advisor members who let us know that there is limited seating for the planetarium so you need to get tickets for these shows before they run out. We scored a quiet day. We ubered 5 of us there from Ghirardelli for only $27. Aquarium was pretty good as was the planetarium.The rainforest was good but we have a really amazing one in NZ in Dunedin with much larger in fact really huge butterflies that alight on people with more colours and the full life cycle breeding on display. Still it was worth going to see here in San Fran though.
Show less

This place was simply amazing! We were astounded at every turn. What a beautiful building. So much to do here for all ages. Really friendly and knowledgeable staff!! Highly recommend you put this at the top of your list!

If you are looking for a space to find a bit of every living form along with a sneak peak of our stars and galaxies, this is the place to be. We spent one full day here and never felt bored for a second. Be it butterflies, fishes, fun facts on nature, science and space, you name it. Specially for kids, this is an absolute marvelous place to have a gala time.
Show less

This is for 21+ - great fun to hang out with a gang of friends (birthday/Christmas present), enjoy science, have a cocktail and leave the kids at home with the grandparents/babysitter. Have an early dinner before or late dinner after (make reservations though!). So much fun.
Show less

It was my first time coming to the California Academy of Sciences and was really impressed by it despite its expensiveness. If you're like me, you'd probably need more than 3 hours to fully immerse yourself in what the museum has to offer. The aquariums alone were impressive by themselves. It's not easily accessible though, but Lyft/Uber will easily bring you here. It's also right across the de Young Museum!

Make sure to arrive early so you can sign up for the optional experiences (like the Planetarium).
Show less

I've been wanting to visit this museum since it's facelift so we chose to go when the Pterosaur exhibit came to town. We had a good time and enjoyed all the exhibits but were surprised at the cost of tickets. For two seniors, which there is a small break in price, we paid $70 for the two of us. And if there ever is a next time, we'll bring our own lunch. Two bowls of soup and two sodas came to $39.
Show less

We've been to the Academy probably 20 time with the grandkids over the last few years.
It is a great place for kids of all ages. However, I've noticed the last few times there seem to be some management problems. When we entered there was quite a mess.
You get in a long line to buy tickets, then get in another long line to hand your tickets in to a person who can't figure out which tickets to approve. If you had groupon tickets or tickets purchased by phone she would get confused and send you over to the ever growing ticket line-in the rain. How is it the DeYoung can have one ticket line and the museum with lots of kids requires two long slow lines?
Once inside try not to go into the restaurant. Cost aside, there is not nearly enough seating for the number of people inside. Also skip the 30mins. Earthquake movie. There is not a kid I know who would appreciate this movie! If you can go after 2:00 o'clock, I would. The cafeteria crowd is smaller, the line to get in is shorter and the number of strollers is reduced by at least 75 per cent! (I've never seen so many strollers in one place!). So bring lots of money and come late-it's a great place!
Show less

From open 9:30 to close at 5 pm, the Academy captivated our family with many exhibits. Winter/snow events for the season were good. Many hands-on experiences. Recommend the Dark Universe show in the planetarium for kids over 6 years. Seemed a little pricey compared to other major city's museums/science centers.
Show less

We took our grandkids during winter break and arrived later than we should have. At 11:00 AM it was very crowded but still we didn’t have to wait too long for anything. The one big disappointment was that we didn’t know we had to get tickets for the planetarium in advance right when we entered, and I think it would have been good if we had been notified of that when we bought our tickets.
We were so focused on getting into the rainforest because there was a big line, so by the time we asked about planetarium tickets there were no slots left.
We still had a great time in the rain forest and my little granddaughter kept having butterflies land and stay on her, which was quite a treat.
The kids were never bored and they loved the aquarium too. It was the perfect size and nicely interactive.
We did get stuck at the top of the rainforest with a big line trying to take the elevator down. We tried to walk down and out but then realized that was the only way out.
The food (except for the coffee and pastries) looked bad and we wished we had taken a picnic. We did enjoy the outdoor eating areas during bought a few snacks.
Show less
Ice skating at the Academy of Science

The Academy of Science offered holiday fun for both young and old during the holiday season. Although I could not entice my 6-year-old companion to venture onto the ice, it was fun watching others slipping and sliding around the on the temporary ice skating rink.
The museum offers many favorite exhibits as well as temporary and interactive displays. I decide to become a member so that I can visit as often as I like and the bonus is free admission for a companion. Oh, what a deal!
Show less

The academy is in Golden Gate Park (GGP) across from the DeYoung Museum. Worth several hours to enjoy and explore. As a member of the academy one can enter an hour before the public on Tuesdays and Sunday mornings. If you have little kids it may be worth it then. There are the penguins to see and time it with their feeding schedule.

I find the academy to be magical with the butterfly garden, the planetarium and the narrated programs, the native plant garden on the roof top of the academy and the aquarium below. So much to see you have gauge your time and interest there.

There are places to eat inside but one can consider eating outside GGP along Irving between 7th and 9th Avenues. A number of places to try out.

The academy does have parking available below the DeYoung and is it accessible by Muni lines.
Show less

I went with a family of four, two adults and kids 9 and 4, and they all seem to have had a good time. The kids know only a little English, and it didn't seem to matter that much.

If you're a AAA member, make sure you buy tickets though that site. We saved 20% or more on the tickets (the list price is confusing -- I see around $40 for an adult on the Academy's website, but on the AAA site the list price was shown at $36....AAA price was about $29).

I'm sure I'm in the small minority of visitors who thinks there was TOO much of an environmentally conscious tinge about the presentation. We went to see the penguin feeding and our speaker -- professional and glib, but somewhat disconnected from his audience -- went on about extinction and sustainability for maybe 25% of his discussion. He's talking mainly for kids, who just want to see a couple of penguins fight their guts out for a fish (at least the boys do), using multi-syllabic words many can't understand yet.

These children will get all this stuff twice over in the classroom. Can't they avoid the lectures about how horrible their grandparents made the planet and just have some cool fun here?
Show less
Well worth the cost of admission!

Interactive and educational for all ages. Super layout so that it never seems like it’s too crowded. Beautiful displays and helpful staff. Lots to do and learn. Great food court with healthy choices. We were there for four hours and didn’t even come close to seeing the entire museum. I was shocked at first when it was a steep price tag to get in, but ended up understanding the cost. Planetarium included in price. If you plan on going more than once in a year, splurge on the annual admission.
Show less
Aquarium a great excursion for kids!

Though the museum was mobbed on a holiday weekend, the flow at the front door moved pretty fast and once inside were able to maneuver around pretty easily.

We focused on the aquarium, and it did not disappoint. Large, mesmerizing tanks of rainbow colored fish loom over you, and the space is great for slowly taking in the sights and hanging out with family.

The cafeteria was also mobbed -- less successful in the traffic flow, it gets very clogged at choke points and makes for a stressful experience, but the food was surprisingly good for a museum, if inconveniently laid out among different lines. So if you want a salad and also a burger, you are waiting in two long lines instead of one.
Show less

After standing in the line for over 30 minutes, we finally got in.
It was a very busy day and we felt like the museum did not count the people who got in, so the busyness felt overwhelming, even unsafe.
However, the most shocking thing of the entire experience was the aquarium, with the albino alligator in particular. the animal is kept in captivity in a very small area with no room to really swim or move around. even more, with all the kids and people around the animal must be in distress and it does not feel okay the watch this all going on.
I thought in 2017 (almost 2018) we, as human, would have passed the stage of using animals solely as entertainment.
Furthermore, there are more animals at the museum put into the small aquarium, with kids banging on the glass windows. pure animal cruelty; PLEASE DON"T GO THERE.
Show less
Fantastic and meaningful trip for family !!

Brought my 8,10 year old and spent almost the whole wonderful day and it’s still not enough!

The planetarium is fantastic and we watched a few shows incl earthquake, universe etc ...definitely an eye opener and brings science to life beyond what we see on everyday life. We also love the aquarium which by the way is more impressive than Monterey Bay Aquarium .

The only regret was that we did not have time to explore the rest of the park outdoor which was a waste of a good day of sunshine!

Show less
A great place for all ages

Located in Golden Gate Park the California Academy of Sciences is a terrific place to visit anytime. The exhibits are first-class and extremely comprehensive. We visited in late December when ice skating was available in the East Garden. Although it was very crowded, the cafe, in true California foodie fashion, was excellent—they even had sushi. Despite our timing (Christmas break) we were able to park easily.
Show less
A bit too young but fun
Our teenage daughter was not all that impressed but we can see that the under 10 crowd would enjoy this activity.
Always a hit with the kids...

We have been members here for awhile and love it. Every time we visit SF from Sacramento we take our daughters (10 and 7). The exhibits change often and the fact they have a planetarium, aquarium and rain forest dome under one roof helps satisfy everyone in the family.

Definitely get here early. If you arrive just before opening you can usually find free 4-hour parking along the street in Golden Gate Park. Will save you $25 over the underground lot.

By noon the place is always packed. The first two hours are always the slowest and, as such, the best time to really see everything.

The planetarium shows fill up quick, so go get the free reserved tickets as soon as you get inside. You can pick your showtime and then you’re charters to get in and experience the wonderful shows that rotate through.
Show less

This facility has several attractions, but we came specifically to see the aquarium and were not disappointed. The entry fee gets you into the rain forest attraction, the planetarium, and access to the restaurant and gift shops well. This aquarium is one of the best I’ve ever seen! The seadragons are amazing (my favorite)… as are all of the many types of fish and eels. We lucked out and were there when the octopus was out of his hiding place. (One of the people standing by us said that he is a member of the aquarium, and had never seen the octopus in all the times he had visited.) There is a gigantic tank in one room with the most colorful fish you’ve ever seen, and rows of seating so that you can just sit and relax for a bit. It is very soothing. There is also an open tank with starfish in it, where you can actually touch them and see what they feel like. Each tank seems to have a wonderful creature in it from another world. I will attach some pictures so you can get a feel for what awaits you. You have got to go see this place to believe it!
Show less
Great place to all the family
This place was great, we had a great time. Perfect for adults and kids. The dining area has several types of food which is very good.
Good but not as good as the Hype

Very impressive building and the fact that in one place you can visit a rain forest, aquarium and planetarium but each exhibit just good rather than outstanding. Very good for a family but then very expensive
A must see if you have children.

All kids and adults will love this. All the locals use this regularly, so it’s not just a regular tourist spot , although it still is very busy and there are queues. Be prepared for that and it will make your visit more enjoyable. Really worth it.
Show less
Fun way to spend a rainy day

Well worth the price with lots to see and do. Need a full day at the museum and definitely make time to watch the shows at the planetarium.the tickets are free to enter the planetarium but have to be obtained prior to the show at the ticket desk inside the museum.the rainforest and aquarium are treats for people of all ages. As a group of adults we thoroughly enjoyed our visit there.
Show less

I love this place. There is such variety, and not so much information that it is overwhelming. I visit once a month as a member, and there is always something new. I adore the Sky Shows. All exhibits bear repeating for greater depth. Warm and personable feel, not overwhelming. It is a planetarium, an aquarium, and a natural history museum all in one. Spend the day, and go up in the free 7-story observation deck attached to the deYoung Museum before 4 pm. Walk around Golden Gate Park. San Fran at its best!
Show less

This is a great place to take the whole family. Lots to see and do here. It is rather pricey and if you've been a couple of times a lot of the stuff is the same.

The best tip is to go for Nightlife if you are 21 and over. The admission is about half of what it is during the day and they play music and they have bars set up everywhere. It's really fun, most of the exhibits are all still set up and running during Nightlife. But like almost every time you come here, be prepared to wait in line!

The earthquake simulator is super fun and I've still yet to visit the planetarium. But Claude the alligator is my favorite by far!
Show less

With its Rain Forest exhibit, plus the Morrison Planetarium and Steinhart Aquarium, this place is world class and extremely fun. Kids especially would enjoy it, and even older kids like my wife and I (who are over 60!)

Planetarium show promised something exciting ... curved roof layback seats but way to much science and could have been fun if content more general . We all snoozed. Would ha e been nice to receive a program at front door of times of events so u could plan .
Show less

This place is AWESOME! The exhibits are so well-maintained and the whole place is just magical. Plus, there is an albino alligator! The geology exhibit was my favorite. I could spend entire days there.
Great place for all ages and the earthquake experience is so realistic! GREAT TRIP FOR THE WHOLE FAM, with both life science and physical science experiences!

We have been to science museums all over the country, and this stood out as one of the best. The rainforest offers 3 stories of flowers, birds, and butterflies. One butterfly even landed on me. Beneath this exhibit is the aquarium - small, but lots of interesting things. We saw a couple excellent shows at the planetarium. In between were smaller exhibits. We spent the whole day there and enjoyed every minutes.
Show less

We especially enjoyed the rain forest (butterflies and birds flitting about) and aquarium exhibits. We enjoyed a presentation in the planetarium. Altogether, an amazing number of experiences housed under one roof. The cafe seemed to be expensive.
Don’t go on their free day

So we didn’t realize it was a free day..I’ve never seen so many people in a museum..
We waited about 30 minutes to get in- but once we were inside it was so busy we barely could walk. Everything had lines. We waited for the earthquake simulator for about an hour.
I guess since it was free it was nice to check out but I would have preferred to pay to have fewer people. We ended up leaving.
Show less
It’s a out of the world museum, I’ve been at their first location but this one is so increadible that is a must.

Went here as a family of 4. An excellent place to spend a half day. We were there on a weekday. It was very crowded and I imagine it would be worse on weekends.
The food options were horrendously expensive so make sure you take your own snacks and drinks.
Show less

Why did Trip Adviser report that no tickets were available for this museum when I was able to go directly to the museum's website and purchase directly. This is frustrating and diminishes confidence in TA.

I am a high school science teacher and recently found myself in San Francisco for a friends wedding. While the family was preoccupied getting things ready, I took an Uber to Golden Gate Park to explore for the day. What a fantastic time I had!
The Academy of Sciences is FULL of interesting exhibits. It is essentially a planetarium, aquarium, museum of natural history and rainforest all in one. I was there for more than 3 hours. It IS very kid-centric and local schools schedule field trips during the week -so be prepared for crowds of kids. The planetarium shows are first come first served, BUT you can see more than one show in a visit if you visit the kiosk again. The staff were friendly and accommodating.
If you find yourself with more time to spare, the park itself has many other wonderful gems - the botanical garden, the DeWolf Museum and the Japanese Tea Garden.
Show less
Being in our early 30's with no kids we found this place a bit kid-centric. The displays and attractions were more aimed at younger kids. Go to the Exploritorium for a more hands on adventure!
It is really a Museum Like No Other

This is a the only aquarium-planetarium-rainforest-natural history museum on Earth, adventure is around every corner. If you are driving, parking place is far away. If you come by bus, it is preferable. Or take a taxi. You can marvel at the deepest living coral reef tank on Earth. Zoom across the Universe in our 75-foot planetarium. Trek through a butterfly-filled four-story tropical rainforest. In the middle of the tour, we had to stop for a lunch break, go to the cafeteria. Everything is healthy and organic! The aquarium has nearly 40,000 live animals representing over 900 separate species. The Morrison Planetarium is one of the largest and most advanced all-digital domes in the world. Tip: as soon as you arrive, go get the planetarium show first to guarantee your session! The four-story rainforest is a slice of tropical paradise. The Kimball Natural History Museum is loaded with diorama displays and high-tech interactives at the Pterosaurs: Flight in the Age of Dinosaurs. Could not go to the Shake House, a 7.9-magnitude earthquake simulator because the line up was too long... You will have complete fun for an entire day!
Show less

My two boys, ages 6 and 9, really enjoyed this museum. We spent over 4 hours there and still didn't get to see everything. It started to get really crowded (around 2pm) so we left.
As others recommended, we got our Planetarium passes right when we arrived. Then went to the aquarium and rainforest areas. Both these areas were not big but had enough wildlife and educational signs that it did take some time to go through.
We also browsed the gem room, the flying reptile room and the room with the different skulls. We didn't have time to do the earthquake simulation and missed the penguins.
If I were to do it over again, I would have brought more snacks as the line for concession was very long, and get in line for the earthquake exhibit as soon as it opened as that line was long and slow by mid-day.
Nonetheless, it was a great way to spend our morning.
Show less

There's a lot going on here with many different sections, so make sure you allocate plenty of time to visit. The various planetarium shows are cool and free - the narrator for the earthquake one was very good - as is the rainforest exhibit. The informational signs are comprehensive as well. The albino alligator is quite a sight, though it didn't move much at all.
Show less

Maybe we we're a bit jet-lagged, but we got a bit tired fairly soon. However, there are lots of interesting things. And certainly not only for families with children! As somebody else said, if you can bring a pic-nic, the café was expensive and not that good (But certainly not bad!). Still, I think that they could have made more of it, for example, we’d loved to be able to a walk on/along the green roof. However, well worth a visit!
Show less

I really wasn't too sure what to expect when I came here but it is just a bit of everything. There are a few museum exhibits like you would see in a natural history museum.

There is also a very nice aquarium! I spent well over an hour exploring the aquarium part and it was simply amazing. Several viewing tanks with floor to ceiling windows into different environments.

There is a rainforest biodome with lots of butterflies and birds - seemed really cool but at that point WAY overloaded with screaming kids so a little overwhelming.

And finally, there is a planetarium with free tickets to any of the shows! Just stop by the desk to pick up a ticket for the one you want to see. I saw a great show on dark matter.
Show less
Was enjoying the visit until I saw how small the penguin enclosure is. This place should focus on science and let larger zoos have the animals. As Trump would say: Saaaaaad!
Much to see so allow some time

I was the Brit with 2 Californian friends and our time was a bit limited but the museum is full of interesting sections. The planetarium has shows which I think are free to attend and last 20-30 minutes so you get escorted around the universe via this huge cinema screen with an explanation of what's OUT THERE.
It's complex as is the universe so like me, much of it may pass you by but I really enjoyed the show about earthquakes and how the city is in a tricky place! The film explained just how the tectonic plates slide and cause damage.
The aquariums have some wonderful displays with cool lighting so even jellyfish look alluring. The albino crocodile just looks sad and lonely. We managed to see quote a bit but the museum needs a few hours and don't forget to go see the rood garden as the views are great too.
Show less
Loved seeing all the different exhibits and animals! Great for taking pictures and learning cool stuff!

We used the Big Bus to get to and from the park. There are so many areas to the academy which would appeal to everyone. Unfortunately the rainforest enclosure was being renovated when we were there but could still see some of the butterfly's through the window. Such an amazing green energy facility that you could easily spend the afternoon at.
Show less

California Academy of Sciences is an unforgettable way to spend an afternoon in the city with family. The adults loved it. The children didn’t want to leave!! Wear comfy shoes because it is a lot of walking. There is a restaurant onsite. Although many families brought their own food and had a little pick nick. A good time
Show less
Great if you have kids, ho-hum if not

I read all of the reviews on this place and was so excited to get here! We made it our first stop when arriving in San Francisco and couldn't wait to see and do all of the activities listed based on the stellar reviews. Upon coming up the stairs to the California Academy of Sciences, my husband and I were greeted with throngs of children waiting to pour into the museum. We pushed past the crowd and purchased our tickets and entered the venue. There were children literally EVERYWHERE. When I read the reviews, it said this place had a rainforest with more than 1,600 animals. Did they count each and every fish, because it didn't seem as if this were possible. My husband and I walked through the aquarium and while it was quite nice, we thought, "Is this it?". We completed the entire museum in 90 minutes or less. We didn't even stay for a Planetarium show because we didn't want to waste anymore time there waiting for the next showing. Honestly, this place is great for families with young kids, but holds nothing of any real interest for those who have none. We felt that we wasted our money as far as our own entertainment was concerned, but know that a portion of our dollars goes to the upkeep of a lovely museum aimed at families and education. And that's never a bad thing. If you have young kids, this place is a must. If you do not, then hitting the Japanese Tea Garden and taking in the beautiful sights there might be more enjoyable for you. Good luck and enjoy!
Show less
Much to see!!! Many neat crystals and rocks, plenty of local sea life, some fossils, great planetarium show, definitely worth the visit!!!
Great way to spend a not so great weather day

It was the last full day of our vacation. We spent every day up until this one, doing outdoor things. This day was cloudy, windy, with periods of drizzle from time to time so we spent the day here.

This is is the only institution of it's kind in the world. It houses an aquarium, a planeterium, & a natural history museum all under one roof.There are many interactive displays & activities that engage people of all ages
For example the aquarium an exhibit with tidewater creatures like starfish & sea urchins& plants like live kelp with a shadow area so that you may touch these. There is a tunnel whose walls are made out a clear material & when you walk through it, all around you there fish plants& creatures from the Amazon, There is a long bench so that you can sit & observe what is going on around you & here you will find it very peaceful. There fish & creatures from accross the globe from Claude the albino alligator to sea horses as well penguins which you can watch being fed.
There is a planeterium that has regularlyrics scheduled shows. A hall with taxidermist animals from various parts of the world in terms original part of the Academy. Throughout the year there special exhibits many are interactive like one on adaptive evolution or what it feels like to be in a house during an earthquake & how to prepare for that event. During the winter holidays there are live reindeer outside one of the wings of the museum & inside periodic "snow" falls.
Some of the labs are visible to the public & one can see scientists working on investigations that might one day breakthroughs in science.
When you do come be prepared to be engaged, surprised & awed by this fantastic place. Wear your walking shoes & bring a snack as you could spend all day to be able to see what is oferred.

A Visit to California Academy of Sciences

Soon after our coming to California our first place of visit is the famous California Academy of Sciences, where we can see an aquarium, a planetarium and a natural history museum—a sort of three centers at one place. Of course in San Francisco there are many museums like Walt Disney Family Museum, Asian Art Museum, San Francisco Museum of Modern art, Musee Mecanique, Cable car Museum etc. But as most children in our batch were interested in watching various types of plants, fishes and animals, we chose this place which is a must see for everyone. It requires almost one whole day to see so many rare and astonishing things here that we have not seen elsewhere. The academy people deserve our utmost compliments and appreciation for their untiring efforts in preserving all these specimens and in promoting the spirit of science and in creating awareness of caring for our environment and other fellow creatures and beings which have their right to live and grow in their habitats. For this purpose the Academy provided suitable surroundings and simulated conditions for all these creatures to survive without any discomfort and troubles. This Academy is located at Music Concourse Drive on Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, in the heart of the city. This institution started as a society in 1853. In 2008 it was designed by the famous Italian architect, Renzo Piano and re-built in a spacious area. It was opened for public on 27th September, 2008.

The building was constructed in eco-friendly style having a spacious area of four lakh square feet. Nearly 26 million specimens are preserved and looked after here by the managing committee consisting of forty one trustees who allocate duties to executive members. This academy is a scientific and educational institution “dedicated to exploring, explaining and sustain life on earth.”Apart from display of exhibits this academy arranges lectures, workshops, field trips and demo classes on bio-diversity, taxonomy, anthropology, marine biology, herpetology, ichthyology and phylogenetics.
Kimhall Natural History Museum has three sections; The Osher Rain Forest, Aquarium and Africa Hall (the oldest running exhibit). The Rain Forest section is housed under a 90 foot glass dome kept at 82-85 Fahrenheit temperature with 75% of humidity in air to suit the rain forest flora and fauna. Various trees and plants from Borneo, Madagascar and Costa Rica are seen on three floors as we climb the stairs enclosed on both sides by glass covering. Huge palms, mahogany trees, orchids and others with dark green leaves take us into the world of nature filled with so many different kinds of plants and flowers. Colorful butterflies, moths and birds are seen flitting all around. Under the first floor the Amazonian forest is displayed with flooding waters. One can also see various types of reptiles and amphibians kept in glass cases. Nearly 1600 live animals are displayed here and one is surprised to see so many different kinds of snakes and frogs. In Steinhart Aquarium various types of fishes, corals, crabs, sea anemones, urchins, stingrays, star fish, and snails are displayed. The aquarium is the star attraction of this place. Many children love to see the bright colored fish and multicolored corals and urchins.

The Tusher African Hall is another place of attraction to see lifelike models of various jungle animals displayed in glass cases. At the entrance “Human odyssey” the evolution of man is shown by display of various human fossils and skulls. The computer animation of the famous Lucy skeleton shows how changes occurred in physical structure of human species in course of time. The models of African animals like the tiger, the lion, the rhino, the elephant and the antelope are quite realistic and impressive. At one of the hall within a glass enclosure are kept the African penguins which dip and dive in the 25,000 liter water tank. In the East Wing one can see Foucault pendulum, a huge 16-ich diameter brass ball weighing about 238 pounds hung from the ceiling by an aircraft control wire. It demonstrates the earth’s rotating movement on its axis. In the West Wing many geophysical exhibits are shown in various glass cases. There are nearly four hundred types of various mineral rocks and gems in this section.

In the Earthquake section a lot of information is given about the occurrence of earthquakes with details photos and models. The effect of earthquake is practically experienced in the chamber by technological simulation. As we had to hurry to get into the planetarium we did not spend much time there to know about earthquakes. The Morrison Planetarium is one of the largest completely digital planetariums with a spacious dome above measuring about ninety feet in diameter and with a seventy five feet broad screen. The introducer gave a lecture about the theme of earth’s evolution and galaxies with their enormous size and numbers. The appearance and features of Pluto were clearly projected on the screen. But we felt it would be better to give more visual details instead of verbal explanation. Details may be shown on the screen itself. At the Naturalist Center many books, toys, specimens, printed T-shirts, films and interactive games are available. In the main hall skeleton of a blue whale is displayed while in another hall the huge skeleton of Tyrannosaurus Rex is seen. At another place the huge skeleton of 87-foot long blue whale is seen suspended from the roof.

At the Science Project one can look at the scientists working on real, live research projects and also at several smaller exhibits. But most of the scientific research work is carried out in private labs. This institution publishes a journal called “Proceedings od the California Academy of Sciences” to inform people about their latest discoveries and information. In 2011 scientists of this institution went on an expedition to Phillipines and discovered nearly three hundred species quite unknown to science.
This Museum is open from 9.30 a.m. to 5.00 p.m. from Monday to Saturday and from 11.00 a.m. to 5.00 p.m. on Sundays. At present the Rain Forest section has been closed from 5th September to 12th October as renovation works are going on. The entry ticket for adults is 35.75 dollars, 30.95 for senior citizens and for those aged between 12 and 17 years and 25.95 dollars for children below twelve years. The authorities may consider reducing the entry fee to facilitate more people coming to this museum and get enough knowledge and awareness in protection of the surroundings and our fellow creatures as well.

The aquarium was the best part, with aquatic species from across the world; however it is hard to look at all the tanks in a systematic order. The Africa exhibit was interesting, however the penguins at the end seemed extremely depressed in a small enclosure, with no sky light access; very disappointing in comparison to the penguin enclosure at a local zoo in England. The rainforest exhibit had some very beautiful butterflies, however it was clear it is still a work in progress as you could see tanks and creatures in a closed off areas still being prepared. The loss of wonder and knowledge

In the middle of the most amazing man made park in the world, California Academy of Sciences and Steinhart aquarium has had two renovations over it's many years. The first was an improvement, the last one a disaster. When I was a kid it was free, mysterious and awesome. The first renovation added a new greeting hall in the front and you were greeted by a big Allosaurus skeleton. It had many Great Halls. The Hall of Minerals, North American Hall, Steinhart Aquarium, Simson African Hall, Science Hall, Morrison Planetarium, The Hall of Man and more. It was deeply involved in education and it's darkly lit halls let the treasures shine all the more brightly. I'm sure it was responsible for turning many a fascinated child into todays scientists.

Then the mistake. In 2008 the new "Academy" opened. Gone were the Great Halls, gone were all the reptiles surrounding the alligators and crocodiles, gone were the fantastic dioramas painted and sculpted by the finest artists, gone was the playful genius of Gary Larson's "The Far Side" twisted view of science. And gone was the inspiration of the youth.

Instead, they hired an architect who's sole desire, it would seem, was to show off his building and forget about the fantastic wonders that should have been inside. They boast about the "Living Roof"! Who needs a living roof when you are surrounded by Golden Gate Park?!

Now when you pay your outrageous $36 entry, you are greeted not by a dinosaur, but a big restaurant! One of three! Serving regretful food at regretful prices. Food is not why you go to a museum.

It boast a huge "Open Space" with lots of air empty of exhibits apart from printed info panels. Even the great whale skeleton is hung so high that it cannot be fully appreciated.

The Aquarium might have an enormous tank, but the intimacy and fascination are missing. The Planetarium may be state of the art, but what they gained in digital CG they lost when they threw out the Zeiss star projector.

I'm very sad believing that my beloved Academy will no longer inspirer young, would be, scientists as in did in my youth. Two thumbs down. My whole family were members for three generations, I even worked summers there. I will not go back. It has become a money making travesty, not the awe inspiring institute is once was.
